newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU monetary committee meets on EMU budget pact.
newsitem.headline: EU monetary committee meets on EMU budget pact.

text.p: The European Union's monetary committee began a regularly scheduled meeting on Tuesday to resolve outstanding issues on a budget pact for countries joining a single currency.
However, given the contentious nature of the issues involved, there was little hope of a final accord on a budget stability pact ahead of a summit of EU leaders next month in Dublin.
EU monetary officials on Monday said the most likely outcome would be a progress report on the work completed so far, with negotiations continuing into next year.

Tough German demands have so far blocked an accord on a pact that penalises governments running excessive deficits within a monetary union. It is considered by many to be an essential element of economic and monetary union (EMU).
Perhaps the toughest hurdle is agreement on a precise definition of a severe economic downturn which would let governments with deficits above three percent of gross domestic product avoid sanctions.

Germany very much wants a quantitative definition of what constitutes so-called "temporary and exceptional" circumstances. But others say a narrow definition of an economic recession is unrealistic given obvious differences among EU economies.
As a possible compromise officials say the idea of a range, specifying the magnitude of negative growth a country must suffer if it is to avoid penalties, is being considered.

While the parameters are still unclear, the objective would be as follows: if the decline in a country's total output fell within the specified range, a vote among EU finance ministers would be taken to determine whether it was an exceptional situation.
A majority would be needed for such a verdict which would then allow the country to avoid fines. If the decline in GDP was beyond the range, no vote would be needed.
Several other items also need to be resolved.
For example, the initial or fixed portion of a fine and whether there should be a maximum amount.

The European Commission proposed in October that there should be both a fixed and variable component to sanctions, with the fixed portion being 0.2 percent of GDP. They also argued for a maximum of 0.5 percent of total output.
On both counts, officials say there is still debate, with Germany resisting the idea of a ceiling.
Apart from negotiations on the details of the stability pact, monetary officials say the EU's legislative process alone precludes the possiblity of an accord this year.
The deliberations of the monetary committee, comprised of national treasury and central bank officials, will form the basis of talks by EU finance ministers on December 2.
